array.string: In Letter2Word, you compete against your opponent(s) in a turn-based game where the goal is to spell out a word, letter-by-letter, with your opponent. When it's your turn, you choose a letter, then your opponent chooses a letter, and so on as long as the series of letters is part of any dictionary word. (For example, "TEL", "TELEPHO", and "TELEPHONE" are all valid, while "TELEPHONEG" is not.) Once a player picks a letter that doesn't work, points are given to the previous player, and the space is cleared. The game runs on a 3-minute timer, and the player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

The object of WordSmith is to come up with as many anagrams or partial anagrams as you can from the word or phrase given at the start. (An anagram is a word formed by rearranging the letters of another word or phrase.) For example, if you are given the word "existential", you might enter the words "exist", "ten", "stint", "lane", or many others. Longer words are worth more points, so try to edge out your opponent(s) by finding as many longer anagrams as you can in the 2-minute time limit.

In Reveal the Word, you and your opponent(s) are given a set of words with their letters shuffled, and a few hints for each word (definition, synonyms, etc.). The goal is to unscramble as many words as you can in te 2-minute time limit. If you're stuck on a word, you can skip it for a 10-point deduction from your score. Keep in mind that longer, more complicated words are worth more points than shorter, simpler ones.
